qas.question: Along with bridges, tithe barns and town halls, what notable new structures were built during this period?
What method, derived from the Romans, was traditionally used to build ships?
What new shipbuilding method was invented in this period?
What type of rudder was introduced during this period?
What type of sails were first used during this era?

context: The construction of cathedrals and castles advanced building technology, leading to the development of large stone buildings. Ancillary structures included new town halls, <a0_0>houses<a0_0/>, bridges, and tithe barns. Shipbuilding improved with the use of the <a2_0>rib and plank<a2_0/> method rather than the old Roman system of <a1_0>mortise and tenon<a1_0/>. Other improvements to ships included the use of <a4_0>lateen<a4_0/> sails and the <a3_0>stern-post<a3_0/> rudder, both of which increased the speed at which ships could be sailed.
